Row.text: Open borders with all city states

Row.Text: Aragorn II, the son of Arathorn II and Gilraen, also known as Elessar as well as Strider. 16th Chieftain of the Dúnedain of the North; he was later crowned King Elessar Telcontar (March 1, 2931 - FO 120 or SR 1541), the 26th King of Arnor, and the 35th King of Gondor and first High King of Gondor and Arnor, since the short reign of Isildur.
+5 [ICON_Strength] Combat Strength if there is at least one Citadel Guard adjacent.
Théoden was the seventeenth King of Rohan, and last of the Second Line of the royal house of House of Eorl.
+5 [ICON_Strength] Combat Strength against melee units and heal after defeating an enemy.
Elrond was one of the mighty elf rulers of old who lived in Middle-earth from the First Age through the Third Age and into the beginning of the Fourth Age.
+5 [ICON_Strength] Combat Strength against Melee and Cavalry units.
Receive +5 [ICON_Strength] Combat Strength in land tiles adjacent to Coast.
Receive +5 [ICON_Strength] Combat Strength for fighting next to a Noldor Warrior or a Mithlond Sentry.

Thranduil, son of Oropher, was an Elven king who ruled over the Woodland Realm in the Second and Third Ages. Though inherently cautious, he eventually committed his kingdom to fighting against Sauron in the War of the Ring. He was the father of the elven prince of Mirkwood, Legolas, who was a member of the Fellowship of the Ring.
Receive +5 [ICON_Strength] Combat Strength if there is at least one Silvan Spearman adjacent.

Galadriel was the co-ruler and Lady of Lothlórien alongside her husband, Lord Celeborn, however, neither took royal titles, as they only saw themselves as Guardians of The Golden Wood. She was one of the greatest of the Eldar in Middle-earth, and surpassed nearly all others in beauty, knowledge, and power. She was also the bearer of Nenya, one of the three Elven rings.
Receive +5 [ICON_Strength] Combat Strength if there is at least another Galadhrim Archer adjacent.

Dáin II Ironfoot (or, King Dáin) was the son of Náin and the grandson of Grór, the youngest son of Dáin I of Durin's folk, and was lord of the Dwarves of the Iron Hills in Wilderland. He was a Dwarven King of Durin's Folk, the fifth King under the Mountain, and the Lord of the Iron Hills during the War of the Ring in Middle-earth in the late Third Age.
+5 [ICON_Strength] Combat Strength in your territory or adjacent to your territory.
+5 [ICON_Strength] Combat Strength if there is at least one Dwarven Phalanxes adjacent.
+1 Combat Strength when fighting in Hills and can move over Hills faster.
+5 [ICON_Strength] Combat Strength when attacking ranged and siege units. 50 percent flanking bounes.

Sauron was a fallen Maia, the creator of the One Ring, and the most trusted lieutenant of his master Melkor. After Melkor's defeat in the First Age, Sauron became the second Dark Lord and strove to conquer Arda (Middle-earth), creating the Rings of Power for this purpose. In the Second Age, he was defeated in the War of the Last Alliance by the last line of defense: Elves and Men under kings Gil-galad and Elendil.
Does not suffer combat penalties when damaged.

Saruman was a Wizard, or Istar, who lived in Middle-earth during the Third Age. Originally, he was the chief of the wizards and of the White Council that opposed Sauron. His extensive studies of dark magic, however, eventually led him to desire the One Ring for himself. Thinking he could ally himself with Sauron and then betray him, Saruman allied Isengard with Mordor in the War of the Ring
Does not suffer combat penalties when damaged.
+7 [ICON_Strength]Combat Strength when attacking, and -7 [ICON_Strength] Combat Strength when defending. Does not suffer combat penalties when damaged.

Gorkil was a powerful goblin ruler during the Third Age. He and his armies took control of the abandoned outpost in the Ettenmoors in Angmar, formerly owned by the Witch-king of Angmar. Sauron uses Gorkil to control the goblins and serve his will. He also owns and raised a rare, gigantic scorpion.
+10 [ICON_Strength] Combat Strength when fighting on Hills.

Suladân, also known as the Serpent Lord, lived during the War of the Ring, he led the Desert-Men forces (Haradrim) with merciless precision. He was considered a mysterious being, perhaps even a monster of sorts, by the soldiers of Gondor, a shadow that would strike like an assassin and kill without fault, and even by his own loyal troops.
-5 [ICON_Strength] Combat Strength for all adjacent enemy units.
+10 [ICON_Strength] Combat Strength when fighting on a continent other that your [ICON_Capital] Capital's.

Angamaitë was a descendant of the rebel Castamir and carried on the traditional hatred against Gondor. In TA 1634, King Minardil was at Pelargir without fear of any attack. Angamaitë and Sangahyando soon learned about this through spies and sacked the city, killing Minardil and seizing great amounts of treasure.
Angamaitë likes people who declare surprise wars

Khamûl was one of the nine Ringwraiths, second to the Witch-King, in Middle-earth after Arnor was defeated. During the Third Age, he held Dol Guldur as Sauron's lieutenant. After the Witch-King was slain, he became the Lord of Nazgûl for a short period.
+5 [ICON_Strength] Combat Strength when fighting against cavalry.
+5 [ICON_Strength] Combat Strength outside of own borders.

Kîonid II and his twin Mîonid were princes of the tribes of northern Khand who were as well offspring of the Wainriders as they were of the Variags.In the War of the Ring the brothers united their realm with Sauron´s great eastern Army.
Yields 60% of defeated units' [ICON_Strength] as [ICON_Gold] on combat victory.
This unit heals every turn, even after moving or combat.

The Witch-king of Angmar was the leader of the Nazgûl or Ringwraiths, and Sauron's second-in-command during the Second and Third Ages. Once a Númenórean king of men, he was corrupted by one of the nine Rings of Power that had been given to the lords of men, and became an undead wraith in the service of Sauron. After the first defeat of Sauron in the War of the Last Alliance, the Witch-king fled to Angmar, a kingdom he ruled for over thousands of years until he returned to Mordor to lead Sauron's armies in the War of the Ring.
+5 Combat Strength when fighting in Hills
+5 Combat Strength when fighting in Tundra and Snow.
+5 Combat Strength when fighting in Hills.
+5 [ICON_Strength] Combat Strength when fighting on a continent other that your [ICON_Capital] Capital's

Elendil was the father of Isildur and Anárion, and the first High King of Gondor and Arnor and first King of all the Dúnedain. He was known as a great warrior, a wise king, and a heroic figure among the Dúnedain, who loved every man, woman and child of Arnor and Gondor, and was loved by them in return. He was killed by Sauron during the War of the Last Alliance. He was known as the greatest warrior of all the Dúnedain.
+5 [ICON_Strength] Combat Strength in your territory or adjacent to your territory.

Círdan was the lord of the Falas and then of the Balar during much of the First Age, one of the wisest and perhaps the mightiest of the Moriquendi. He was the bearer of the Great Ring Narya, which he in turn gave to Gandalf. He is one of the three oldest living elves in Middle-earth at the end of the Third Age, along with Galadriel and Celeborn, who were all born during the Years of the Trees. At the end of the Third Age, there were no other elves who had been alive at the start of the First Age.Círdan would sail on the last ship into the West, as he is the Lord of the Grey Havens.

Azog, known also as the Defiler and the Pale Orc, was an orc who lived in the Third Age. He commanded the tribes of Moria from TA 2790 until his death in TA 2799. He was responsible for the death of King Thror and for King Thrain's madness.
Your [ICON_TradingPost] Trading Posts in foreign cities provide +1 [ICON_Production] Production to your [ICON_TradeRoute] Trade Routes passing through.
Commercial Hubs gains 1 [ICON_Gold] Gold if they are next to a Mountain.
Commercial Hubs gains 1 [ICON_Gold] Gold if they are next to a River.

Receive the [ICON_RESOURCE_WINE] Wine. +1 [ICON_Food] Food from [ICON_RESOURCE_WINE] Wine, [ICON_RESOURCE_INCENSE] Incense, [ICON_RESOURCE_COCOA] Cocoa, [ICON_RESOURCE_TOBACCO] Tobacco, [ICON_RESOURCE_COFFEE] Coffee, and [ICON_RESOURCE_TEA] Tea Plantations.
Receive the [ICON_RESOURCE_TOBACCO] Tobacco. +1 [ICON_Gold] Gold to all [ICON_TradeRoute] Trade Routes.
Campus gains +1 [ICON_Science] Science for Forest adjacency.
All melee unit gain +5 [ICON_Strength] Combat Strength when fighting on Hills
+5 [ICON_Strength] Combat Strength when fighting on Hills
Commercial Hubs gains +1 [ICON_Gold] Gold for adjacency to Tundra.
Your units receive double experience from battles they initiate.
+30% Production toward Builders and newly trained Builders gain +1 actions
+20% Production toward Anticavalry units from all the eras since the Classical Era.
+20% Production toward Ranged units from all the eras since the Classical Era.
Holy Sites gains +1 [ICON_Faith] Faith for Forest adjacency.
All districts gain +2 [ICON_Faith] Faith for being adjacent to the Coast.
Commercial Hubs gains 1 [ICON_Gold] Gold if they are next to a Mountain.
+1 [ICON_Faith] Fe for routes between your own cities.
Your Bonus resources behave like Luxury resources, providing 1 [ICON_Amenities] Amenity per type.
Industrial Zone gains +1 [ICON_Production] Production for adjacency to Tundra.
Your [ICON_TradingPost] Trading Posts in foreign cities provide +1 [ICON_Gold] Gold to your [ICON_TradeRoute] Trade Routes passing through.
Your [ICON_TradingPost] Trading Posts in foreign cities provide +1 [ICON_Culture] Culture to your [ICON_TradeRoute] Trade Routes passing through.
Other civilizations' [ICON_TRADEROUTE] Trade Routes to you provide +2 Production [ICON_Production].
Your [ICON_TradingPost] Trading Posts in foreign cities provide +1 [ICON_Gold] Gold to your [ICON_TradeRoute] Trade Routes passing through.
Other civilizations' [ICON_TRADEROUTE] Trade Routes to you provide +2 Faith [ICON_Faith].
+5 Combat Strength when in a district or fort.
Less attack than normal but +1 additional attack if unit has not moved.
+10 Combat Strength when defending vs. melee class units.
+7 Combat Strength vs. units in districts
Adjacent units of a different class get +10 Combat Strength vs. cavalry.
+7 Combat Strength when defending in Woods, Jungle, Hills, or Marsh.
+5 Combat Strength when attacking ranged and siege units.
+10 Combat Strength when defending vs. melee class units.
+7 Combat Strength when defending in Woods, Jungle, Hills, or Marsh.
+7 when attacking melee and ranged units.
Receive +5 [ICON_Strength] Combat Strength in land tiles adjacent to Coast.
-5 to adjacent enemies and can attack the city walls.
-5 to adjacent enemies, +7 Combat Strength vs. units in districts and can attack the city walls.
Commercial Hubs gains +1 [ICON_Culture] Culture if they are next to a River.
All Plantations gain +1 [ICON_Gold] Gold. Receive the [ICON_RESOURCE_TOBACCO] Tobacco.
Your cities earn +15% [ICON_Culture] Culture whenever you are not at war with any civilization.
Your Encampment districts provide +1 [ICON_TradeRoute] Trade Route capacity each.
Regional effects from your Industrial Zone and Entertainment Complex districts reach 3 tiles farther.

Your districts provide +1 [ICON_GreatPerson] Great Person point of their type ([ICON_GreatWriter] Great Writer, [ICON_GreatArtist] Great Artist, and [ICON_GreatMusician] Great Musician for Theater Square districts).
Three tile impassable natural wonder. It appears as a Mountain and provides +2 [ICON_GOLD] Gold to adjacent tiles.
All alone it rose and looked across the marshes to the forest. The Lonely Mountain! Bilbo had come far and through many adventures to see it, and now he did not like the look of it in the least.
Two tile natural wonder. It appears with Cliffs adjacent to water and provides +2 [ICON_Culture] Culture and +1 [ICON_Food] Food.
“And Rauros, golden Rauros-falls, bore him upon its breast. 'O Boromir! The Tower of Guard shall ever northward gaze To Rauros, golden Rauros-falls, until the end of days.”[NEWLINE]– Aragorn
Three tile impassable natural wonder. It appears as a Mountain and provides +1 [ICON_GOLD] Gold and +2 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture to adjacent tiles.

“There is the land where our fathers worked of old, and we have wrought the image of those mountains into many works of metal and of stone, and into many songs and tales. They stand tall in our dreams: Baraz, Zirak, Shathûr.”[NEWLINE]– Gimli
One tile impassable natural wonder. It appears as a Mountain and provides +2 [ICON_FAITH] Faith and +1 [ICON_Production] Production to adjacent tiles.

“There is only one way: to find the Cracks of Doom in the depths of Orodruin, the Fire-mountain, and cast the Ring in there, if you really wish to destroy it, to put it beyond the grasp of the Enemy for ever.”[NEWLINE]– Gandalf
Two tile impassable natural wonder. It appears as a Mountain and provides +1 [ICON_FAITH] Faith and +2 [ICON_Production] Production to adjacent tiles.

“Bullroarer, who was so huge that he could ride a horse. He charged the ranks of the goblins of Mount Gram in the Battle of the Green Fields, and knocked their king Golfimbul’s head clean off with a wooden club. It sailed a hundred yards through the air and went down a rabbit-hole, and in this way the battle was won and the game of Golf invented at the same moment.”[NEWLINE]– Gandalf
Two tile impassable natural wonder. It appears as a Mountain and provides +2 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture and +2 [ICON_Production] Production to adjacent tiles.

“Gundabad. An old enemy, the ancient kingdom of Angmar. This fortress was once its stronghold, it is where they kept their great armories. Forged their weapons of war. In another age, our people waged war on those lands. My mother died there.”[NEWLINE]– Legolas
One tile impassable natural wonder. Provides +2 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture and +2 [ICON_Science] Science to adjacent tiles.
“Immeasurable halls, filled with an everlasting music of water that tinkles into pools, as fair as Kheled-zâram in the starlight.”[NEWLINE]– Gimli
Three tile impassable natural wonder. It appears as a Mountain and provides +1 [ICON_Science] Science and +2 [ICON_Production] Production to adjacent tiles.
Beyond there glimmered far away, as if floating on a grey cloud, the white head of tall Methedras, the last peak of the Misty Mountains.
Four tile natural wonder. It appears as Marsh and provides +2 [ICON_Faith] Faith and +1 [ICON_Culture] Culture.

Dreary and wearisome. Cold, clammy winter still held sway in this forsaken country. The only green was the scum of livid weed on the dark greasy surfaces of the sullen waters. Dead grasses and rotting reeds loomed up in the mists like ragged shadows of long forgotten summers.
Two tile natural wonder. Provides +1 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture and +3 [ICON_Faith] Faith to adjacent tiles.

“This is the Window of the Sunset, Henneth Annûn, fairest of all the falls of Ithilien, land of many fountains. Few strangers have ever seen it. But there is no kingly hall behind to match it. Enter now and see!”[NEWLINE]– Farimir
Two tile natural wonder. It appears as a Lake and provides +2 [ICON_Faith] Faith, +2 [ICON_Food] Food, and Fresh Water.
“This pillar marks the spot where Durin first looked in the Mirrormere. O Kheled-zâram fair and wonderful! There lies the Crown of Durin till he wakes.”[NEWLINE]– Gimli
Two tile natural wonder. Provides +1 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture and +2 [ICON_FOOD] Food to adjacent tiles.

“There is somebody that I know of, who lives not far away. That Somebody made the steps on the great rock—the Carrock I believe he calls it. He does not come here often, certainly not in the daytime, and it is no good waiting for him. In fact it would be very dangerous.”[NEWLINE]– Gandalf
One tile impassable natural wonder. Provides +1 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture and +2 [ICON_Faith] Faith to adjacent tiles.
“The Paths of the Dead! Why do you speak of them? If there be in truth such paths, their gate is in Dunharrow; but no living man may pass it.”[NEWLINE]– Théoden
